a1: ROI (Return on Investment) measures the percentage gain or loss on an investment relative to its cost. An ROI of 50% means you earned half of your initial investment as profit.
a2: Annualized ROI converts the total return into a yearly rate, allowing comparison of investments held for different durations. It uses the compound annual growth rate (CAGR) formula.
a3: ROI = ((Final Value - Total Cost) / Total Cost) Ã— 100. Total cost includes the initial investment plus any additional costs.
a4: A good ROI varies by investment type. Stock markets historically return 7-10% annually, while real estate may target 8-12%. Any positive ROI means you made a profit.
a5: Yes, a negative ROI indicates a loss on the investment. The calculator shows negative values in red so you can quickly identify losses.
